BE11:13am

Supply constraints in mining will intensify this year, especially in copper, and demand should be resilient in 1H17. While Chinese construction activity should slow in 2H, the ongoing recovery in global industrial activity is an offsetting positive. Copper is our preferred commodity for 2017 as we now forecast a market deficit this year. We have increased our copper price forecasts, and we reiterate our Buy ratings on Glencore, Freeport and First Quantum.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Favorable macro conditions: The mining sector should benefit from Chinese infrastructure spending, the ongoing global recovery in industrial activity and manufacturing, potential fiscal stimulus in the US, a higher oil price, and an increase in inflation expectations. Demand conditions are likely to be supportive, at least until China's National Congress meetings in 3Q/4Q17. Speculative demand for commodities is also likely to be strong if the dollar continues to strengthen as traders in China have been buying commodities as a backdoor strategy to get long the US$. Counter-intuitively, a weaker dollar could lead to lower commodity prices in the short-term as dollar weakness could spark an unwind of speculative longs. All things considered, we expect resilient demand for most commodities in 2017, but prices should be volatile along the way.

Copper supply problems: Copper mining companies slashed capex and in some cases high-graded mines during the downturn. Operating risk has increased as a result, and unexpected disruptions are likely to be a prominent factor in the copper market this year. There is also risk of strikes as labor negotiations will be difficult, including at Escondida, the world's largest copper mine. We now forecast a small (82kt) copper market deficit this year due to lower supply projections, and we have increased our copper price forecasts to fully reflect the improving fundamental outlook (Exhibit 15).

Funds are still underweight mining: Based on our recent conversations with investors, it is clear to us that many long only funds are still underweight mining. As fundamentals remain supportive and the copper price increases, we would expect these funds to capitulate and buy. Mining share prices are likely to go materially higher as a result.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Since you mention banks, though Lloyds getting a push from Barclays.

BE11:18am

Strong returns: UK economic prospects remain challenging and uncertain but less severe than we had previously anticipated. On revised economic assumptions, our detailed credit quality analysis suggests that provisions will peak below 35bp and we expect the net interest margin to rise helped by the interest rate environment and the planned MBNA credit card acquisition. Together these drive c15% upgrades to our underlying earnings estimates in 2017 and 2018, suggesting that Lloyds can make a c13% RoTE over the next three years and return close to a quarter of its market cap to shareholders. We expect this to drive share price outperformance and upgrade Lloyds to Overweight with a 75p price target (from Equal Weight, 55p).

BE11:19am

More margin expansion: We believe that a more favourable interest rate environment and the planned acquisition of MBNA’s credit card book should see Lloyds’ net interest margin rise from 2.70% in 2016 to 2.76% in 2019, compared to our previous 2.60% forecast. Higher medium-term interest rates reduce the headwind from the structural hedge rollover which should now be offset by falling deposit costs. Along with the BoE’s Term Funding Scheme largely offsetting mortgage spread compression, this leads to a 4bp decline in Lloyds’ standalone margin with the MBNA acquisition adding 10bp.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Modest credit quality deterioration: Recent UK economic data has been more robust than previously anticipated suggesting a better outlook, particularly in terms of growth and unemployment. Our detailed regression analysis identifies the historical relationship between provisions and key variables, suggesting a relatively shallow credit cycle, reflecting slow growth rather than a recession, limited deterioration in unemployment and low interest rates. Lloyds’ balance sheet mix and quality puts it in the middle of the pack among UK banks with a modelled 30bp peak provision charge in 2018, with our 35bp forecast more conservative reflecting economic uncertainty.

BE11:19am

Strong capital returns: Helped by stronger earnings and despite anticipating higher PPI provisions, some RWA inflation and the planned MBNA acquisition, we expect Lloyds to return over £10bn of capital to shareholders through to 2019, equivalent to almost a quarter of its current market cap or a little under 15p per share. Most of this should come from growing the ordinary dividend, indicating its sustainability while maintaining a 13% CET1 ratio looks consistent with a strong 2016 stress test result.

PM11:22am

The expectation of future interest rate rises in the wake of the US presidential election has seen an increase in volatility and market activity. This has benefited the company’s traditional products areas such as interest rate derivatives, fixed income and Treasury products, all of which have been generally weak in the years since the credit crisis (as the yield curve in developed markets has progressively become lower and flatter).

Revenue is expected to be up 12% in sterling from last year’s £796m, implying c£891m. This is equivalent to a 4% gain in constant currency indicating a strong final quarter because the constant currency growth was 2% at the 9 month stage and there was a tougher comparative in Q4 (+4% in the final two months on 2015). The implied revenue of £891m would be £24m (3%) ahead of our current forecast of £867m. While no indication is given on profitability at this stage, we would expect at least half of the revenue beat to drop to the bottom line (after broker compensation). This would add around £12m (10%) to our current £122m operating forecast.

PM11:22am

The statement indicates that more detailed guidance around the pro-forma combined performance for 2016 (i.e. including the acquired ICAP business and also, we expect, any update on synergies) will be given on 14th March at the final results. Therefore we would currently be cautious around making any material adjustments to our 2017 and 2018 pro-forma forecasts, accepting that the recent positive market influences will also have been seen in the acquired operations.

At last night’s closing price of 433p and before any change to forecasts (provisionally up 10% as noted above) TP ICAP trades on 11.4x our Dec ’16 underlying eps of 38.0p, rising to 13.8x our pro-forma Dec ’17 eps of 31.4p. The prospective Dec ’16 dividend yield on a forecast flat 16.85p dividend would be 3.9%.

Our last published fair of 375p was based on applying a 12x multiple to our pro-forma Dec 17 forecasts. While we see scope to push up these forecasts (we’ll wait for the re-presented P&L at the final results before formalising), we would be reluctant at this stage to be more bullish on the rating given the structural pressures still prevalent in the IDB market. Therefore, although we expect the shares to respond positively this morning, we retain a HOLD recommendation.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Update. Company reports that results will be ‘comfortably ahead’ of previous guidance citing progress in all businesses. This is being driven primarily from the cost actions and sales efforts (e.g. into industrial and aggregates markets in the US) rather than any significant changes in end markets. ECS - US coal seeing some increase in activity note that coal production is up c40% from spring 2016 lows albeit remaining at historically low levels. Key actions taken in America, particularly on the cost front, appear to be gaining good traction. Australia is ahead of the previous year despite order levels being flat as miners focus on costs even as commodity prices improve. We note Rio recently announced their 2017 capex budget including increase Australia investment. AEP is seeing some upside at CDI as the rig count improves and Hallitte seals business benefiting from internal actions. Overall therefore the group is benefiting from internal actions and the lack of negative operational gearing / first shoots of a recovery suggesting that the positive impact of operational gearing is still to come as commodity markets improve.

BE11:27am

And Peel Hunt .....

BE11:27am

AEP is seeing an improving trend in order intake and customer
enquiries in Oil & Gas, reflecting its strengthening market
position and a further rise in the US rig count. The Medical
businesses are performing well and in line with expectations.
ECS – some increase in order intake in North America, from
very low levels. Outlook – whilst market conditions remain
similar to November, the group is enjoying market share gains.
As a consequence, the Board envisages that the Group's results
for the current financial year will be comfortably above previous
expectations. Forecasts: We expect to increase our August 2017
PBT by c10% to £34m (12.8p). The group is clearly now on an
upward trajectory and we anticipate more material upgrades for
FY2018E as the key end markets continue to recover, enhanced
by further market share gains. On our indicative forecasts, the
shares are trading on an August 2017 PER of 18.5x, falling to
15x August 2018 & 1.3% yield. We are increasing our target
price to 300p and upgrade our recommendation to Buy.

BE11:28am

11:29 am

You'll remember the shares came off by nearly 50% at the end of last year when Poland, its biggest market, proposed a new price cap on interest charges.

PM11:30am

BE11:30am

That still awaits clarity, confirmation or whatever. But in the meantime, we get the Polish Tax Chamber getting the knife in.

11:30 am
PM11:31am

IPF is sounding really wounded

PM11:31am

http://www.investe...1701060700085192T/

BE11:31am

The challenge is over how IPF's transfer pricing policy relates to an intra-group arrangement with the UK bit

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And how collection revenue might or might not have been backdated to 2008. And 2009. And perhaps 2010, which is still under audit.

BE11:33am

Management estimating a £134m hit, which is versus £160m of current debt headroom.

BE11:33am

Let me cut to Shore to summarise from here.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Management says that, having taken legal advice, it strongly disagrees with the interpretation of the tax authority and intends to appeal the decision to the District Administrative Court, a process that is expected to take up to a year to conclude. In order to do this the group will need to pay £20m (c9p per share) comprising of tax and associated interest, although this will be treated as an asset on the balance sheet with no provision set against it (meaning there will be no income statement impact). Should the group lose its appeal then we would assume this payment would be unrecoverable thereby requiring the amount to be expensed along with any additional costs. The group also expects it will need to set aside an additional similar amount to cover costs for the 2009 year, although it is unlikely that subsequent years will be challenged by the tax authority until the outcome of the appeal process is known.

It is now quite clear to us that the Polish authorities (whether it is the Ministry of Justice or Polish Tax Authority) are seeking to clamp down heavily on high cost credit operators and have IPF firmly in their sights, although we do not think the two processes are directly linked. While IPF will no doubt put up a strong defence in respect of both the proposed price cap (by the MOJ) and tax changes (by the PTC), the likelihood of a successful outcome for the group remains highly uncertain. Should IPF be unsuccessful in its defence then the Polish business, which accounts for around half of group profit, is likely to be rendered unviable, in our view. Not only would this lead to a sharp reduction in ongoing profitability, but it would also probably result in significant one-off closure costs. It is likely in such a scenario that banking covenants could be breached ahead of the residual book being collected out, noting that the interest cover covenant stands at a minimum of 2.0x versus the 3.6x reported by the group in H1 2016. However, we understand that management would look to use surplus liquidity that subsequently builds up in order to try to buy back outstanding bonds (potentially at a discount to face value) and reduce the interest costs.

BE11:33am

As a result of these issues, forecasting future earnings and dividends with any confidence is extremely difficult at present, thus rendering our own and existing consensus forecasts somewhat. The range of potential outcomes is very wide and this makes it incredibly difficult to value this stock. At current prices, we think the market is assuming a high probability that the Polish business will be rendered unviable. The bear case is therefore predicated on regulatory pressure being an ongoing material issue across multiple jurisdictions that ultimately renders the entire group unviable or that it may need to raise more equity to cover one-off closure costs and pay down debt. The bull case is that the relevant authorities will not want to force lending underground and will therefore water down their requirements, albeit we would be more inclined to advise existing holders to use any associated bounce in the shares to cash out rather than encourage new investors into the stock. While we therefore leave our recommendation under review given the high degree of uncertainty, our overall stance is one of caution.

BE11:35am

And Numis. James Hamilton, who's always a guy with a strong view and was a champion of the IPF story for a long time.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We continue to believe the home credit model is a viable and inclusive product, allowing customers to manage expenses they cannot afford out of regular income. Large proportions of the population in emerging markets are excluded by the banks and, while IPF’s APR is high, it is reflective of the impairment risk of the underlying customers. Furthermore, the approval rating of IPF amongst its customers is exceptionally high in comparison to other lenders. Assuming the populist wave that is sweeping politics doesn’t cover the entire globe, excluding large swathes of the population from access to finance, we believe IPF has a future of long term growth. With the ongoing political risk we acknowledge that IPF will continue to trade at a substantial discount valuation. Assuming there is no further substantially negative legislation the shares are compellingly cheap. That is, however, a very large assumption.

BE11:43am

We do not believe WPUS’s recent woes are structural or related to its smaller scale. We show that profitability in merchant acquiring in the US is more a function of a company’s merchant mix (SMBs matter), channel-to-market, and platform consolidation. WPUS appears to have addressed all those issues and we now expect margins to recover from H2.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

We believe eCom will continue to require high investment over time. However, the renegotiation of large contracts in H1 16 provides a sounder base for growth for H2 17 and after. Also, eCom’s net take rate is already low compared with competitors (see Sector section). This may somewhat limit the risk of steep price erosion over the medium term.

BE11:44am

(@erlkin: there was a Bloomberg story about that a while back, by Tracy Alloway. I recommend it highly.)

BE11:45am

Small retail in the UK continued to do well in H2 16, performing even better than in H1. This is a strong support to WPUK’s net revenue growth and should to some extent offset the waning boost from Interchange regulation in H2 16.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We raise our growth assumptions on WPUS and Global eCom. At group level, we now expect revenue growth of c10% in 2017 and c8% in 2018 (previously 8% and 7%). We also raise our profitability assumptions on WPUS: we now expect an EBITDA margin of 24.8% in 2017 and 26.7% in 2018 (previously 24% and 26%). At the group level, we raise our EBITDA by 4% for 2017e and by 7% for 2018e. We are now broadly in line with consensus on both years.

BE11:45am

WPG has de-rated from a 12m-fwd EV/EBIT of c21x at the start of 2016 to c16x today. In line with our revised earnings forecasts, our DCF-based FV/sh. climbs to c360p. Our SOTP points to c320p. We raise our TP by 17% to 340p from 290p and upgrade the stock to Outperform.

BE11:46am

So, that's that. And if anyone wants to talk about the other payment companies mentioned in the note they're welcome to contact us via the usual routes.

Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,439, up 14 (+0.98%), High: 1,457, Low: 1,439, Volume: 287.07k
Rotork PLC (ROR:LSE): Last: 259.10, up 9.4 (+3.76%), High: 260.80, Low: 253.90, Volume: 1.55m
BE11:57am

Neutral on IMI and Halma.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

(@Boncoeur: the HMRC guidance note seems to say contradictory things in rather woolly terms. See if you can make sense of it: https://www.gov.uk...r-cryptocurrencies )

BE11:59am

Setting the scene; five prevailing themes
1) Improving growth prospects: We are most attracted by potential for earnings inflection at Rotork and organic sales growth improvement at Smiths. 2) Niche leading positions, nuanced end markets: OSG diverges materially (CY17 greater than 10% pts) across the four stocks; we favour O&G, healthcare and security over general industrial, utilities. Aftermarket opportunities prevail. 3) Uses of cash, portfolio opportunities: Given scant divisional synergies and recent management action, Smiths stands out, in our view. 4) M&A potential: we view Rotork and IMI as the most likely M&A candidates and include M&A components weighted 15% in our valuation. 5) Weak GBP: Smiths is the greatest beneficiary (US 47% sales). GS foresees further weakness in 2017, a potential source of upgrades.

BE11:59am

Buy Rotork (£2.80 PT): 2016 marks the trough

We forecast a 2016E EBIT margin 650bp lower than the 2014 peak but recovering 65% by 2020, driving 54% earnings growth (GSe sector +21%) and sector-leading ROIC improvement (+9% pts by FY20). O&G capex inflection, 3Q order stabilisation and easier comparatives bode well. We are 7% above 2017 Bloomberg EBIT consensus.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Buy Smiths Group (£16.70 PT): Return of OSG can narrow discount

We forecast 3% OSG from FY18 (vs. 5y history of 0.7%) driven by (1) Cyclical rebound in O&G exposed John Crane; (2) Portfolio optimisation in Medical; (3) Structural growth in Detection. Portfolio pruning and improved cash conversion (5y historical average 57%) can further help to narrow the 24% sector discount. We are 4% above company-compiled cons FY17 EBIT.

BE12:00pm

the other two are fair value. That's that.
